msgSnippet: I worked in WebMacro before and the lead there (actually the boss) seted up an testing environment that can generate the output text of a WebMacro page. Then

I worked in WebMacro before and the lead there (actually the boss) seted up
an testing environment that can generate the output text of a WebMacro page.
Then we use a Java-Perl tool to parse the resulting string.  For example, if
we want to assert title, we just ask for a mach of the regular expression
(*<html>*<head>*<title>[Title Text]</title>*</head>*</html>).

We ended up (through refactoring) having a customized test case that can do
things like assertTitle, assertCheckBoxName, assertCheckBoxSelected.  (Off
the thread, what we have built through testing and refactoring was so
comprehensive and efficient that I was totoally converted into XP. :)  )

Anyway, I have never done this but I always think it might be possible for
you to parse the JSP page and generate the output.  In this way, one doesn't
have to generate all the DOM like stuff (which can be complicated) and all
the environment objects can be mock objects (easy to setup values) so that
the testing is concentrating on the JSP page only.  If it works for WebMacro,
I don't see why not in JSP.

The Java-Perl link is here:
http://www.savarese.org/oro/

Shane
